journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Response time of magnetorheological fluids and magnetorheological valves under various flow conditions

article-meta.aff: 1Advanced Materials and Devices, Inc., Reno, NV, USA
2Composite and Intelligent Materials Laboratory, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Nevada, Reno, NV, USA

author-notes.corresp: Faramarz Gordaninejad, Composite and Intelligent Materials Laboratory, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Nevada, Reno, NV 89557, USA. Email: faramarz@unr.edu

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue on 12th International Conference on Electrorheological Fluids and Magnetorheological Suspensions - Part 2

abstract.p: In this study, the response times of magnetorheological fluids and magnetorheological fluid valves are studied under various flow configurations. Two types of valving geometries, annular flow and radial flow, are considered in the magnetorheological fluid valve designs. The transient pressure responses of magnetorheological fluid valves are evaluated using a diaphragm pump with a constant volume flow rate. The performance of each magnetorheological valve is characterized using a voltage step input as well as a current step input while recording the activation electric voltage/current, magnetic flux density, and pressure drop as a function of time. The variation of the response time of the magnetorheological valves under constant volume flow rate is experimentally investigated. The Maxwell model with a time constant is employed to describe the field-induced pressure behavior of magnetorheological fluid under a steady flow. The results demonstrate that the pressure response times of the magnetorheological fluid and the magnetorheological valves depend on the designs of the electric parameters and the valve geometry. Magnetorheological valves with annular flow geometry have a slower falling response time compared to their rising response time. Magnetorheological valves with radial flow geometry demonstrate faster pressure response times both in rising and in falling states.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The response time of magnetorheological fluids (MRFs) to an external magnetic field is a few milliseconds. However, the overall response time in MR devices is a function of electromagnetic parameters, the capabilities of the driving electronics, as well as the operation conditions. Therefore, the overall response time of an MR device depends on the internal device design parameters. This is important in the design consideration of MRF dampers, which have gained considerable attention in land vehicles’ suspensions (Wang and Gordaninejad, 2007). The fast response time of MRFs, when subjected to an external magnetic field, is a key advantage in numerous MR applications. It is reported that the response time of MRFs is typically less than one millisecond (Jolly et al., 1999). However, the overall response time of MR devices is dominated by electromagnetic parameters and the capabilities of the driving electronics. Therefore, most of the MR devices cannot be operated with such a fast response time (less than 1.0 ms) due to the limitations of the electromagnetic design (Yang, 2001). This warrants studying internal device design parameters for the effect of response time on the performance of an MR device.

Several attempts have been made to characterize the response time of an MR device and MRF itself. However, no commonly accepted procedure has been developed. Koo et al. (2006) defined the response time of an MR damper as the time required to reach 95% of the maximum damping force and estimated the time response of a commercial MR damper to be 25 ms. Zhu (2005) determined the response time of a disk-type MR damper to be less than 2 ms where the step current reaches 90% of its final value. Milecki (2002) applied a step voltage to activate linear and rotary MR dampers. The damper piston was moved with a constant velocity, and the damping force history was measured, when the voltage was switched on and off. It was found that the MR damper response time was between 30 and 180 ms and was heavily dependent on the value of the applied voltage.

Kavlicoglu et al. (2007) examined the response of a control system and a limited slip differential (LSD) clutch in three different regions. Region 1 was defined as the time interval between the controller switching off and switching on. The MRF LSD clutch is at the off state during this interval. Region 2 was defined as the time interval between the controller switching on and the first acceleration point of the MRF LSD clutch output shaft. Region 3 was defined as the time interval between the first acceleration point and the point where the output shaft reaches the steady-state velocity. They observed that the response times in all regions are functions of input current and input velocity. The response times reduce by increasing input current and input velocity. It was found that, when particle volume fraction in the MRF was kept constant, the response time of the system, including the computer, the controller, the clutch, and the MRF, varies between 20 and 65 ms, depending on the input current and input velocity.

Chooi and Oyadiji (2005) investigated the response time of MRFs under shear rotation of parallel plates. They demonstrated that the overall torque transfer response time was significantly affected by internal system parameters, such as applied activation current, particle volume fraction, and particle surface coating. They found that the system response time decreased significantly as the activation current and particle volume fraction increased. They also experimentally determined that coating of the particles with a thin layer of silicone dioxide helped reduce the response time.

Goncalves et al. (2006) investigated the response time of MRFs in flow mode using a slit channel device. The authors introduced dwell time to represent the response of MRFs when subjected to a magnetic field. The time response can be as low as 0.45 ms when maximum yield stress of 63.2% is attained at dwell time. However, Laun and Gabriel (2007) pointed out that this response time is a hydraulic time constant of the device rather than the MRF response time.

Laun and Gabriel (2007) also investigated the response time of an MRF using a commercial plate–plate magnetorheometer by applying step current input. They used Maxwell-type equation to describe the MRF behavior and derived the MRF response time by subtracting the switching time of applied magnetic field from the torque transfer function. It is found that the MRF response time is between 1.8 and 2.8 ms under step coil current test. Choi and Wereley (2002) compared the characteristics of electrorheological (ER) fluid- and MRF-based systems, based on the time response and dynamic force range by using a monotube damper with single rod. They found that the ER valve has faster response time than the MR valve at the different Bingham numbers. Nguyen et al. (2008) developed an optimization procedure based on the finite-element method to determine the optimal geometry of the MR valves. The time response of the valves was also taken into account in the optimization problem by considering the inductive time constant as a state variable.

In summary, the reported response times of MRFs and MR devices cover a broad range of 0.1–100 ms, depending on the method applied. In most cases, the system response time was determined rather than that of the MRF itself.

The contribution of this study is to present the dynamic response of MRF flow through two different valve geometries, which have similar electrical properties such as resistance and inductance. The effect of MR valve geometries on the pressure response of the MRF flow is also evaluated. The rising response time is defined as the time required for a system property to rise from its initial state to two-thirds of the maximum value under a step excitation input. Conversely, the MRF valve falling response time is defined as the time required for a system property to fall from its initial maximum state to one-third of the maximum value. Rising and falling response times of the MR valves under constant volume flow rate are experimentally investigated. Dynamic response time of the MRF valves are tested using two different power sources: voltage power supply feeding a constant step input and current driver also feeding a constant step input. In order to obtain the response time of the MRF itself, rather than that of the system, the Maxwell model with a time constant is employed to describe the field-induced pressure behavior of the MRF under a steady flow. This study aims at developing design guidelines that can be utilized to reduce the dynamic response times of the MR valves, which are basic components used in most MR devices.

sec.title: Experimental setup and methods
sec.p: There are two flow geometries that are studied in this work. Figure 1(a) and (b) illustrates these two different MRF valve geometries. In the annular valve geometry, the electromagnetic coil is wrapped on the annulus, which is placed within the fluid flow in order to permit the application of magnetic flux density normal to the flow direction. A controllable valving area where the fluid is sheared between the annulus and the outer housing is created. The second MRF geometry, that is, the radial valve geometry, consists of two fixed disks. The electromagnetic coils are wrapped on the spool, which is placed outside the flow as shown in Figure 1(b). The MRF flows in the gap between the disks in radial direction, while the magnetic flux density lines are perpendicular to the flow direction.

caption.p: Schematic representation of MR valve geometries.
MR: magnetorheological.

sec.p: To investigate the response time of the MRF valves, a diaphragm-type pump is used along with a pressure bypass valve to provide a constant volume flow rate of 0.246 L/s. A silicone-based MRF with a particle volume fraction of 32% is used as a working fluid. The average size of the particles used in the working fluid is 5 microns. Two pressure transducers are used to measure the pressure drop, ΔP, across the MR valve. A current shunt is used to measure the activation current supplied to the MRF valve. A hall sensor measures the magnetic field strength inside the MR gap prior to the flow of the MRF induced by the coil. A simple mechanical relay with a square wave control signal generator is used to provide a step input to the MRF valve. The measurements from the pressure transducers, current shunt, hall sensor, and control signal are obtained and recorded by a computer processor utilizing LabVIEW data acquisition software. The specifications of the experimental setup are presented in Table 1.

caption.p: Experimental setup specifications.

tr.td: Coker diaphragm pump—3 HP, 1750 r/m, 3.9 gal/m
Ashcroft—range: 0–3000 lbf/in2; accuracy: ±0.5% full scale; output: 4–20 mA at 12–30 V DC
Bell 5170 Gauss/Tesla Meter—flux density range: 0 to ±20 kG (0–2 T)
Kepco BOP 400-W 50-8M—output range, voltage (V): DC (0 to ±50); current (A): DC (0 to ±8)
Wanner Engineering, Inc.; Hydra-Cell Bypass Valve PWC23AB—maximum 20 gal/m at 500–1000 lbf/in2; maximum temperature: 200°F; inlet and outlet ports: 1 in FNPT; weight: 6 lbf

fn.p: BOP: Bipolar Operational Power; DC: direct current; FNPT: Female National Pipe Thread

sec.p: The schematic of the experimental setup is shown in Figure 2. Once the square wave control signal is activated, the mechanical relay is closed and the electric current is supplied to the coil according to the reference voltage input, which is generated from a voltage power supply or a current driver. As the electric current is applied to the electromagnet of the MRF valve, the magnetic flux is produced, which produces a high flow resistance across the MR valve. It is possible to subtract the mechanical delay time of the relay from the total pressure time response. However, since the system behavior is nonlinear, the simple rule of superposition cannot be applied.

caption.p: Schematic representation of the experimental setup.
MR: magnetorheological; DAQ: data acquisition.

sec.title: MR valve designs
sec.p: In order to compare the performance of MRF valves with different flow geometries, two different types of MR valves are constructed with a fully active pressure drop of 1379 kPa (200 lbf/in2) and similar electromagnetic properties. The annular valve has two coils. There are two ways to connect these coils: a series connection and a parallel connection. The parallel connection is used in this study because it has faster electromagnetic response time. Table 2 lists the electromagnetic parameters of these two MRF valves. The activation current required to obtain the maximum pressure drop of 1379 kPa (200 lbf/in2) is exactly the same for both valves. Important design parameters of the MR valves are listed in Table 3.

caption.p: Properties of two types of MR valves.
MR valves design parameters.

sec.title: Results and discussions
sec.p: Dynamic response time of two types of MRF valves under pulses with constant cycles generated by both voltage power supply and current driver are tested. Bipolar Operational Power (BOP) Supply is used in order to provide required voltage or current input to the system. Output of Kepco BOP 400 W is capable of both sustained direct current (DC) and the replication of arbitrary alternating current (AC) waveforms. Voltage and current outputs can be controlled smoothly and linearly through the entire rated plus and minus ranges. Details of the BOP supply are provided in Table 1. Figure 3 shows the typical normalized pressure response of the 1379-kPa (200-lbf/in2) annular flow MR valve subjected to a step input using voltage power supply. Figure 4 shows the typical magnetic field response of this annular flow valve. The rising response time is defined as the time required for a system property to rise from its initial state to two-thirds of its maximum value. Conversely, the falling response time is defined as the time required for a system property to fall from its initial maximum state to one-third of its maximum value.

caption.p: Annular MR valve: typical pressure response. The pressure is normalized by dividing maximum pressure of 1379 kPa to step input voltage signal.
MR: magnetorheological.
Annular MR valve: typical magnetic field response to a step input voltage signal.
MR: magnetorheological.

sec.p: From Figures 3 and 4, it can be observed that the magnetic response time of 85 ms dominates the overall pressure response time, which is found to be 110 ms. Also, shown in Figure 4, the period time from t1 to t2 is the presence of the mechanical relay delay time, which is basically the time from the control signal being turned on to the point where the electric current begins to flow in the system. The mechanical relay delay time is found to be around 4 ms and is negligible compared to the total system rising response time of 110 ms.

The radial flow MR valve has major improvement in response time when compared to the annular flow MR valve. Table 4 shows the results of the rising (trise) and falling (tfall) response times for the two MRF valves, which are tested in the same procedure as mentioned above. It is noteworthy to mention that the rising response time of MR valves with radial flow geometry is slower than the falling response time. However, the MR valves in annular flow geometry have a very slow falling response time compared to the rising response time. This might be due to the residual magnetic field inside the MR valve in annular flow geometry being significant when the activation current is shutdown. The effect of flow geometry on the pressure response time of MR valves can be observed by comparing the response times of the two MR valves. The comparison is relevant because the overall resistance (R), inductance (L), and capacitance (C) of the annular and radial valves are nearly identical making the transient response of the electrical circuits similar. Therefore, the difference of derived response times of the two MR valves can be contributed to the flow profiles in different geometries. Another significant difference of the two MR valves lies in arrangements of the embedded electric coils. There are two separate coils inside the annular flow MR valve, while there is only one coil in the radial flow MR valve. It is found that the response times of the radial flow MR valve are faster than that of the annular flow MR valve. Activating two coils would produce interaction of magnetic flux density inside MR valve; as a result, the magnetic field response would be slower than activating one coil. Figures 5 and 6 show experimental results of the magnetic field strength response in the MR gap for the two MR valves. The magnetic field was measured in an air gap without the MRF. These tests were performed to understand how the magnetic field responds within the MR gap.

caption.p: Pressure response time comparison for annular and radial MR valves.
Magnetic field response: annular flow valve.
MR: magnetorheological.
Magnetic field response: radial flow valve.
MR: magnetorheological.

sec.p: It is observed that the annular flow MR valve has a much faster rising time, when the valve is activated without MRF contained in the valve. With no fluid flow, the rising magnetic field response time is 20 ms compared to 85 ms with the fluid flow. It appears that the MRF flow disturbs the magnetic field distribution when the MR valve is activated by an applied voltage compared with no MRF in the valve. This is due to the fact that MRF possesses a higher relative permeability of 7 than air with a relative permeability of 1.

As can be seen from Figure 5, the annular valve has a relatively slow falling magnetic field response time of 92 ms. The radial valve has a slightly faster falling magnetic field response time when compared to the rising magnetic field response time. It may be concluded that both, the fluid flow and the geometry, play a significant role in the magnetic field response time.

In comparison to the voltage power supply, the current driver would improve the response times of the MR devices, significantly. Figures 7 and 8 show typical results for the measured rising and falling dynamic pressure responses of 1379 kPa pressure drop for annular and radial flow MR valves, under a step current signal. It can be seen that the dynamic response time of both the annular and radial MR valves is reduced dramatically by using an electric current driver. Under an applied step electric current of 3.0 A, the falling pressure response time is 29.65 ms, and the rising pressure response time is 30.15 ms for annular flow MRF valve. While the falling pressure response time is 20.10 ms, and the rising pressure response time is 21.65 ms for the radial flow MRF valve. The response time is a function of applied electric current. Table 5 shows how the annular valve pressure response time varies by the applied electric current. It is observed that as activation current increases, response time decreases. The measured response times of radial flow MR valve for different applied currents are shown in Table 6. Similar to the annular MR valve, the response time decreases with increasing activation current, and the rising response time is always slower than the falling response time. Table 6 also shows that the falling response time is nearly independent of the activation current. Compared to the annular MR valve, the radial flow MR valve has a faster response time both in rising and falling, which is consistent with the previous investigation using voltage power supply.

caption.p: Annular MR valve: dynamic pressure drop versus time subjected to a step input current of 3 A. (a) Rising response and (b) falling response.
MR: magnetorheological.

Normalized transient magnetic flux density B(T) versus time for electromagnetic coil of annular flow MR valve and fit by equations (3) and (4), respectively: (a) step-up (τ = 11.1 ms, B0 = 0.66) and (b) step-down (τ = 9.5 ms, B0 = 0.69).
MR: magnetorheological.
Pressure response time of the annular flow MR valve activated by current driver.
Pressure response time of the radial flow MR valve activated by current driver.

sec.p:
The dynamic response time of the MRF is derived from the overall pressure response time of the MR valve system under a constant volumetric flow rate by using the Maxwell model with a time constant (Laun and Gabriel, 2007). It is assumed that the pressure drop across the MR valve at a constant volumetric flow rate, Q, depends on the absolute value of the magnetic flux density, B. For mathematical simplicity, the steady-state pressure,
P
s
, is assumed to be proportional to the absolute value of the applied magnetic flux density, B, where f is the experimental constant. For annular valve geometry, f is 1082 kPa/T, and for radial valve, f is 784 kPa/T

The effect of a magnetic flux density variation on the pressure response is described by a simple Maxwell model in which a dynamic response time,
θ
, of MRF is given by
The transient magnetic flux density, after a coil voltage step is applied on the following single exponential function, is given as

where
τ
stands for the time constant of the electromagnetic circuit,
B
0
is the steady-state magnetic flux density, t is the step-up time, and t′ is the step-down time. Substituting equations (3) and (4) into equation (2), one obtains analytical expressions for the transient pressure response of MR valves under an applied magnetic field B, as follows

If
τ
is determined, then
θ
can be obtained through fitting experimental data for the pressure response history by using equations (5) and (6).

Figures 8 and 9 demonstrate the experimental results of the transient magnetic flux density, B, for the annular and radial flow MR valves, respectively, under a step current excitation. The step-up and step-down magnetic field responses are fitted by using equations (3) and (4), respectively. Both the rising and falling time constants of electromagnetic coil for the two MR valves are obtained. The smooth lines are fitting curves shown in Figures 8 and 9. The values of the fitting parameters are also shown in Figures 8 and 9. Results show that the step-up magnetic field responses are slightly slower than the step-down responses for both MR valves. Although annular and radial MR valve coils have similar electromagnetic properties, the radial MR valve yields faster response time than the annular MR valve in generation of magnetic field.

caption.p: Normalized transient magnetic flux density B(T) versus time for electromagnetic coil of radial flow MR valve and fit by equations (3) and (4), respectively. (a) Step-up (τ = 8.5 ms, B0 = 0.73) and (b) step-down (τ = 9.5 ms, B0 = 0.70).
MR: magnetorheological.

sec.p:
Since the measured transient pressure drop across the MR valves has distinct fluctuations under constant volume flow rate, it is difficult to obtain a constant dynamic response time,
θ
, of MRF in such flow conditions. However, a range of the MRF response time could be estimated through different fits of the transient pressure drop by means of equations (5) and (6), which cover the transient pressure drop fluctuations. As can be seen from Figure 10(a) and (b), in the annular flow MR valve, the response time range of 22.0–12.5 ms is pertinent to describe the rising transition of the MRF, whereas the response time range of 14.2–7.7 ms is more pertinent for the falling transient.

caption.p: Experimental results of pressure response for annular flow MR valve under a constant volume flow rate excited by a step coil current and fit by equations (5) and (6), respectively. (a) Step-up and (b) step-down.
MR: magnetorheological.

sec.p: It is interesting to note that the dynamic response time of MRF depends on the flow conditions. As shown in Figure 11(a) and (b), in the radial flow MR valve, the obtained response time of MRF ranges from 5.8 to 1.4 ms for rising transition, whereas the response time ranges from 2.5 to 8.3 ms for falling transient. All the response times of MRF for rising and falling transient obtained in radial flow valve are less than that obtained in annular flow valve.

caption.p: Experimental results of pressure response for radial flow MR valve under a constant volume flow rate excited by a step coil current and fit by equations (5) and (6), respectively. (a) Step-up and (b) step-down.
MR: magnetorheological.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The dynamic response times of MRF valves are not only dependent on the design of electric parameters but are also dependent on the design of the valves’ geometry. Radial flow MR valves yield faster pressure response times both in rising and falling states compared to annular flow MRF valves. The pressure response times decrease with increasing activation current for each MRF valve in the rising state. However, the falling times for each MRF valve are independent of the activation currents. The dynamic response time of the MRF itself in annular flow valve ranges from 22 to 12.5 ms for the start-up transition, and from 14.2 to 7.7 ms for the shutdown transition. In the radial fluid flow valve, the response time of MRF ranges from 5.8 to 1.4 ms for start-up transition and from 2 to 8.3 ms for shutdown transition.

ack.p: The authors would like to thank the National Science Foundation for supporting this study. Also, the authors would like to thank Mr Mark Miller for his assistance in the experimental setup and testing.
